title-group.article-title: Application of the health belief model to explain pre-conception care among women with sickle cell disease: a cross-sectional study

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Pre-conception care (PCC) in mothers with sickle cell disease (SCD) is essential to reduce the risk of morbidity and mortality. PCC is not commonly utilized by women of reproductive age. The reason behind this should be assessed using health education theories. This study aims to apply the health belief model (HBM) to explain the adoption of PCC among SCD women.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A cross-sectional study was conducted in Iran from March 2021 to June 2021. Women with SCD were selected through a systematic sampling framework using the Iranian integrated health system. A demographic, knowledge, HBM, and PCC questionnaire were used as instruments. Pearson’s correlation was used to investigate the relationship between HBM constructs and PCC. The effect of health beliefs on PCC was analyzed using a path model, in which the observed HBM variables predicted PCC behavior.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Out of 413 participants, 13 incomplete questionnaires were excluded (Response rate 96.8%). A significant association was observed between women’s and husbands’ education with the PCC adoption. Pearson correlation test revealed a significant relationship between PCC and HBM constructs; with positive and significant correlation coefficients of 0.651 and 0.599, self-efficacy and perceived susceptibility had the highest correlation with the PCC. Based on the path model analysis, perceived susceptibility (0.26) and self-efficacy (0.36) substantially influenced adopting PCC. The fit indices of this model were acceptable (GFI = 0.98, AGFI = 0.95, CFI = 0.99, and RMSEA = 0.04).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Knowledge, perceived susceptibility, and self-efficacy are the most important determinants of performing PCC. Knowing PCC’s most influential and decisive components will help us plan educational content and effective interventions.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12884-025-08070-5.

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a progressive monogenic disease characterized by unpredictable, acute, life-threatening episodes and chronic complications such as hemolytic anemia and end-organ damage [1]. It manifests with varying severity, resulting in significant morbidity, poor quality of life, and premature death [2]. During pregnancy, SCD can become more severe [3]. Early reports on the outcome of pregnancy in women with SCD showed a nearly universally negative outcome for mother and child. Based on the findings of a meta-analysis, pregnancy among individuals with SCD is linked to a higher likelihood of intrauterine growth restriction, premature birth, abnormal fetal heart rate and intrauterine fetal death, low birth weight, anemia, infection, preeclampsia, and higher risk of the cesarean [4]. Still, the outcome has dramatically improved with advances in medical care, particularly the introduction of pre-conception care (PCC) [5].

The occurrence of sickle cell trait and SCD in southern Iran is estimated to be 1.43% and 0.1%, respectively [6]. From our clinical point of view, as a common disease in Iran, particularly in Hormozgan province [6], and due to high maternal mortality of SCD [4], paying attention to this group of society and conducting the necessary studies to reduce the mortality of pregnant mothers is one of the health priorities of the province. Recently, the maternal health administration in Iran developed a comprehensive PCC used for pregnant women with SCD. One of the essential steps to have a normal pregnancy is to perform PCC, and since expectant mothers with SCD are more at risk due to pregnancy changes, performing PCC in this group is essential, and all efforts should be made to maximize the participation of this group in PCC. Healthcare facilities in Iran provide comprehensive services for women with SCD with a particular focus on risk assessments, including checking the individual’s general health status, modifying lifestyle, prescribing supplements, and providing specialized medical consultation [7].

However, it should be kept in mind that before designing any intervention to increase participation in PCC, questions about the target group, such as “What is their level of involvement in PCC? What is their level of awareness and attitude? What is their health opinion on SCD? How can they be encouraged to become more engaged in PCC?” Answering such questions will lead to a better understanding of the target group and the existing infrastructure for intervention design. For this purpose, this study was conducted to explain the PCC among women with SCD based on the health belief model (HBM). The HBM can describe how health-related beliefs and factors influence maternal behaviors, aiding in the prediction of a woman’s likelihood of adhering to PCC. It is crucial to inquire about women’s health beliefs regarding PCC as this informs the creation of nursing and midwifery interventions that can influence hospital guidelines and provide assistance to women navigating decisions about PCC.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: A cross-sectional study was conducted in Hormozgan province, the southern region of Iran, with a high prevalence of SCD [6] from March 2021 to June 2021.

sec.title: Sampling
sec.p: All women of reproductive age with SCD living in Hormozgan province willing to participate in a study were included. Illiterate and mentally disabled individuals were unable to participate in the study because they could not respond to the questionnaire. Women with SCD were selected through a systematic sampling framework using the Iranian integrated health system. The Iranian integrated health system is national for recording, updating, and maintaining Iranian household health data. This national system keeps every Iranian family member’s vital medical information and disease records. The integrated health system associated with each university can share individual information with authorized users from the university and research team members to conduct research and monitor the health status of individuals, with approval from the university’s code of ethics.

We searched for records of each woman’s records on the integrated health system using the keyword SCD to identify eligible individuals. All women of reproductive age with SCD were contacted by phone and asked if they planned to have a baby. Those with positive answers were invited to participate in the study after a comprehensive explanation of the purpose and process of the study; informed consent was taken from the eligible participants. Eligible samples were given a questionnaire.

Based on the previous study [8], the sample size of 413 was calculated, assuming a standard deviation of 5.8, considering an error of 5%, a test power of 80%, and an effect size of 0.8, based on the following formula:

sec.title: Evaluation instruments
sec.p: Given that no existing standard questionnaire was available, a questionnaire was developed by the research team based on public databases and the results of other studies [9, 10]. A structured questionnaire was used to collect information from participants. A demographic questionnaire, knowledge questionnaire, HBM questionnaire, and pre-conception activities questionnaire were used in this study. The questionnaires used in this study, including the original version in Farsi and an English translation, can be accessed as supplementary files. (Supplementary file 1)

The HBM Questionnaire, a 49-item questionnaire with six subscales, was created to assess participants’ health beliefs about SCD and pre-conception activities. The HBMQ severity subscale was a seven-item, five-point Likert-type scale that asked women whether they thought SCD was a severe condition (e.g., “Maternal and fetal complications increase if I did not PCC”). The response options ranged from “strongly agree” to “strongly disagree”. The scale scores ranged from 5 to 35, with higher scores indicating that SCD was perceived as a more significant threat.

The HBMQ susceptibility subscale was a 10-item, five-point Likert-type scale that asked each woman to consider what she thought was true about an SCD in her situation (e.g., “Pregnancy can be risky even for a young woman with SCD”). The response options ranged from “strongly agree” to “strongly disagree”. The scale scores ranged from 10 to 50, with higher scores indicating a higher perceived risk of SCD.

The HBMQ barrier subscale used an eight-item, 12-point Likert-type scale to assess women’s perceptions of barriers to PCC (e.g., “PCC is expensive”). Each item’s response options ranged from “strongly agree” to “strongly disagree.” The scale scores ranged from 12 to 60, with higher scores indicating a more excellent perception of barriers to obtaining prenatal care.

The HBMQ benefits subscale used a seven-item, five-point Likert-type scale to assess women’s perceptions of the benefits of pre-conception care. Women were asked to consider what they thought was true about the benefits of pre-conception care (e.g., “By participating in PCC, I will know the right time to get pregnant “). Each item’s response options ranged from “strongly agree” to “strongly disagree.” The scale scores ranged from 7 to 35, with higher scores indicating that pre-conception care was perceived to have greater benefits in preventing SCD adverse events.

Women’s self-efficacy, a woman’s perception of her ability to get PCC, was measured using a 10-item five-point Likert-type scale in the HBMQ (e.g., “I can participate in PCC activities”). The answer choices ranged from “strongly agree” to “strongly disagree”. Scale scores ranged from 10 to 50, with higher scores reflecting higher self-efficacy for accessing pre-conception care.

Cues to action, which refer to the factors that help individuals make health-related decisions, were conceptualized as triggers for engagement in pre-conception activities. Advice from relatives, friends, and healthcare providers as an external trigger and the reasons for the necessity of participation in pre-conception care from the patient’s point of view as an internal motivation is a crucial factor guiding women to participate in pre-conception care. Cues to action were measured using the HBMQ subscale. Women were asked to answer “Yes” or “No” to the role of others in deciding to participate in pre-conception care.

The knowledge questionnaire consisted of 18 multiple-choice questions (e.g., “Preterm birth is common in pregnant women with SCD?“). The answers were “Yes,” or “No,” or” Do not know”. Correct answers received one point each, and not knowing the answer or incorrect answers received no points. Possible scores, therefore, ranged between 0 and 18, with a higher score indicating more awareness.

To assess PCC adoption, we asked them about their adoption of 12 commonly recommended behaviors regarding SCD based on standard guidelines [11] during the study period. The activities included taking 5 mg of Folic acid, avoiding smoking, achieving a normal BMI, performing lab tests, vaccination, cervical cytology test, dental visit, avoiding contact with cats, discontinuing Hydroxycarbamide three months before conception, visiting a hematologist, genetic screening, and retinal screening. The answers were “Yes” or “No”.
The demographic factors of each participant, including age, education, occupation of both women and their spouses, and socioeconomic status, were recorded in a simple questionnaire.

A team of nine experts in field health education, epidemiology, obstetrician, and reproductive health was responsible for the validity and reliability of the questionnaire. Minor amendments were made to the wording and order of the questions to achieve a more logical layout. A pilot study was conducted with 30 women to test the items’ comprehensibility and establish the questionnaire’s reliability. The overall Cronbach’s alpha coefficient of the pilot study ranged from 0.69 to 0.91, indicating that the instrument had a high internal consistency.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The results were analyzed using SPSS software (version 25). Mean and standard deviation were used to provide descriptive statistics of quantitative variables, and frequency and percentage were used for qualitative (categorical) variables. The results of quantitative variables were reported as mean, standard deviation (S.D.), or frequency (percentage). The relationship between demographic variables and the behavior of participating in PCC has been investigated through a one-way analysis of variance. Pearson’s correlation test was used to investigate the relationship between variables. We tested the effect of health beliefs on PCC by using a path analysis model, in which the observed HBM variables predicted PCC behavior. We chose path analysis because building a model with path coefficients allows for simultaneously estimating causal relationships among all variables and examining the model’s goodness of fit [12]. The goodness-of-fit index (GFI) was used to assess the model’s explanatory power, and the adjusted goodness-of-fit index (AGFI) was used to delineate its stability. Furthermore, the comparative fit index (CFI) and root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) were used as indicators of relative fitness. Previously, values indicating model acceptability were specified as 0.9 for GFI and AGFI, 0.1 for RMSEA [13], and 0.95 for CFI [14]. We used the Eq. 6.1 software for pathway analysis. The p < 0.05 was considered as significant. The robust Maximum Liklihood was used for estimation.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Out of 413 participants, 13 incomplete questionnaires were excluded (Response rate 96.8%). The average age of the participants was 27.19 ± 4.27 years. The average age of the spouses of the participants was 30.09 ± 4.64 years. The educational level of most of the participants and their spouses was a high school diploma (72.5% and 50.5% respectively). Most participants were housewives (72.5%), and their spouses were employees (88.7%). Regarding socioeconomic status, 17.3% said they were poor, 56.7% said they were average, and only 26% said they were desirable.

In Table 1, the relationship between demographic variables and PCC adoption has been investigated through a one-way analysis of variance. The results showed a significant association between women’s and husbands’ education with PCC adoption.

caption.p: The differences in PCC scores based on demographic characteristics

table-wrap-foot.p: Data are presented as Mean ± Standard deviation

sec.p: Correlation analysis between HBM constructs with the PCC adoption using the Pearson correlation test is given in Table 2. The findings revealed a significant relationship between PCC and HBM constructs. With positive and significant correlation coefficients of 0.651 and 0.59, self-efficacy and perceived susceptibility had the highest correlation with the PCC. (Table 2)

caption.p: Correlation of pre-conception care with health belief construct

sec.p: We performed path analysis to investigate our initial hypothesis that knowledge, perceived severity, perceived susceptibility, perceived benefits, and self-efficacy promoted PCC while perceived barriers inhibited PCC. The results are summarized in Table 3, and the path diagram is shown in Fig. 1. Based on the results, knowledge (0.22), perceived susceptibility (0.26), and self-efficacy (0.36) had the most substantial influence on adopting PCC. The fit indices of this model were acceptable (GFI = 0.98, AGFI = 0.95, CFI = 0.99, and RMSEA = 0.04) (Table 4).

caption.p: The effect of health beliefs on adopting pre-conception care
Path model of pre-conception care among women at reproductive age with sickle cell disease
Fit indices for path analysis of health belief construct on pre-conception care

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The study’s main goal was to investigate women’s adopting PCC, which included performing or not performing a set of health behaviors. The critical point is that taking care of health before pregnancy is difficult because unplanned pregnancies are common in our society. A meta-analysis examined 49 articles in Iran, with a total sample size of 43,061 cases, to determine the prevalence of unintended pregnancy, which was found to be 30.6% [15]. However, healthcare providers have always regarded PCC as an ideal health behavior.

Demographic factors have always been influential in deciding whether or not to engage in healthy behavior. Several factors, including age, marital status, insurance coverage, education, employment status, and family income level, are effective in adopting PCC [16]. A study conducted in Ethiopia on the general population found that young women with higher education are more willing to commit to PCC [17]. Another study also in Ethiopia found that marriage and living with a partner are deciding factors in receiving PCC among women of reproductive age [18]. Some studies pointed to people’s economic status as an important reason for not receiving PCC, so people who were uninsured or living in poverty did not receive PCC [19, 20].

Our findings indicated a relationship between the individual’s education and the spouse’s education with PCC, which means that people with a high education or spouses with a high education were more involved in PCC. Such results have been reported in previous studies. A study conducted in Malaysia on 1347 women of reproductive age showed that participation in PCC increased four times in women with higher education [21]. Another study in Nigeria also pointed out that there is a relationship between women’s education and PCC, so PCC was more common in women with higher education than women with less education [22]. Most studies have pointed out that educated people are more aware than people with less education [23].

In line with previous studies, our findings revealed a strong correlation between the knowledge of participants and the level of participation of people in PCC, implying that the higher the level of knowledge of people, the higher the level of involvement in performing PCC. The path analysis also revealed that women’s knowledge was strongly influenced by adopting PCC. Evidence similar to this finding can be found in the literature review [20, 21].

However, knowledge solely is not the only factor predicting behavior change. Health education experts have presented proven effective and valuable models by incorporating various psychological and social science theories to change behavior [24, 25]. The HBM is one of these models. According to this theory, two critical factors influencing the adoption of desirable health behavior are the individual’s perception of the threat of disease and the belief that the benefits of adopting a protective health behavior outweigh the costs [26]. A group of psychologists proposed this model to explain why some people use health care while others do not.

According to several studies, perceived severity is an important factor influencing a person’s decision to engage in or refrain from a health behavior. For example, a survey of 200 women in Ghana revealed that perceived severity was the most influential factor in increasing the number of people participating in cervical cancer screening tests [27]. Another study on 400 men aged 40–70 found that men with a higher perceived severity score were more likely to participate in prostate cancer screening tests [28]. In contrast, a study on the relationship between health belief model structures and colorectal cancer screening in a population over 70 years old found that a higher perceived severity score played no role in screening [29]. In our study, a significant relationship existed between people’s perceived severity and adopting PCC.

According to the HBM, behavior change will only happen if an individual believes they are at risk of maintaining their current behavior. This condition is called perceived susceptibility [30]according to the study’s hypothesis, people who believe they are more at risk due to SCD are more likely to seek PCC. Our findings revealed a significant relationship between people’s perceived susceptibility and their participation in PCC. This means that people who believed SCD could have serious consequences were more willing to participate in PCC. The path analysis also revealed that perceived susceptibility strongly influenced adopting PCC. The importance of perceived susceptibility as a practical construct in performing a health behavior such as colorectal cancer screening [31]breast cancer screening [31]HIV testing [33]and PCC in overweight and obese women [34] has been demonstrated in several studies. Perceived susceptibility is a common construct in many health behavior theories, and it has been identified as the driving force for engaging in health behavior in various studies [35]. Researchers disagree on the mechanism by which perceived susceptibility influences behavior. Some believe that perceived susceptibility directly affects behavior. This viewpoint is reflected in the HBM, which includes only the direct effects of model components on behavioral outcomes [36]. Others, however, believe that perceived susceptibility does not directly cause a person to decide whether or not to adopt a behavior but acts as a mediator alongside other factors, such as perceived benefits as a stimulus for creating a behavior [37]. According to Fishbein’s integrative model, perceived sensitivity influences intention and behavior indirectly via mediating variables such as attitudes, mental norms, and self-efficacy [38]. Regardless of different points of view, what is important is that perceived susceptibility plays a vital role in creating behavior, and any intervention that can change this component can play a role in performing or not performing a healthy behavior.

Self-efficacy is one of the most important determinants of behavior. According to our findings, self-efficacy had the highest correlation with PCC. The path analysis also revealed that perceived self-efficacy had the most substantial influence on adopting PCC. Consistent with our findings, a study of 165 pregnant women found that participation in prenatal care was significantly higher in those with a higher self-efficacy score [39]. Many studies have highlighted the significance of self-efficacy. Self-efficacy links a person’s way of thinking and intention and the occurrence of specific behavior. Self-efficacy was mentioned as a key element in choosing the delivery method and controlling the fear of natural delivery in Khorsandi et al.‘s study [40]. The study by Darsareh et al., comparing primiparous pregnant women who chose natural delivery versus women who chose cesarean section, found that self-efficacy is the most important factor influencing the choice of delivery method [41].

Perceived benefits are another important factor in deciding whether or not to engage in health behavior. The term “perceived benefits” refers to a person’s belief about the effect of the recommended behavior on risk reduction [30]. The current study’s findings indicated a relationship between perceived benefits and participation in PCC. Many studies have found that perceived benefits are important in performing specific health behaviors such as breast cancer screening [32] and colorectal cancer screening [31]. However, studies such as Dersareh et al.‘s study on the relationship between perceived benefits and delivery method choice revealed that, even though primiparous women valued natural delivery more than cesarean section, they chose the cesarean delivery method [41].

Perceived barriers refer to a person’s perception of the tangible and intangible costs of the recommended behavior, on which a person bases his understanding of the obstacles he will face in performing the target behavior [30]. Among the obstacles that may lead to not adopting a behavior are a lack of time to complete a task, high costs, an inability to pay for that behavior, or a lack of necessary facilities to perform that behavior [42]. The current study found a relationship between perceived barriers and PCC. However, the correlation level of this construct with people’s participation in PCC was lower than that of other HBM components. As a result, it can be stated that the participants in this study reported few obstacles to performing PCC.

In addition to the components mentioned above, some external (caused by the environment outside of the person) or internal (caused by the person) events can cause the person to perform the target behavior. These stimuli are the action guide [30], which in this study refers to the role of the healthcare providers and medical centers. According to the data analysis, midwives, gynecologists, and healthcare providers were identified as the most important sources of information. In addition, the appropriateness of costs, the availability of comprehensive health centers, and the fear of maternal complications during pregnancy were among the factors reported as incentives to perform PCC by women with SCD.

As with any study, this study is not without limitations. Selecting only one behavior theory (HBM) is considered a limitation of this study. Since the health belief model is person-centered and does not investigate the environmental factors that influence people’s behavior, using other behavioral and educational theories, such as the theory of planned behavior, could have produced better results. The sample size may also affect the generalizability of the findings. A larger sample size can increase the generalizability of the results. Although it should be noted that in the case of certain diseases such as SCD, the prevalence of which is high in the province but small compared to other conditions, they can effectively determine the sample size. However, in the case of certain diseases, such as SCD, the prevalence of which is high in the province but low in comparison to other conditions, they can be influential in determining sample size. As is the lack of causal inference between the variables used in this study, using a cross-sectional design is debatable. Because the study relied on self-report measures, social desirability might have influenced the participants’ responses. Illiterate individuals and those with mental health disorders were not included in the study due to their inability to complete the questionnaires. These limitations should be taken into account when designing similar studies in the future. Despite the limitations, our study is the first to use key constructs from the health belief model to explain PCC among women with SCD.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Knowledge, perceived susceptibility and self-efficacy are the most important determinants of performing PCC. Knowing PCC’s most influential and decisive components will help us plan educational content and effective interventions. Further studies with larger sample sizes considering different educational theories are recommended.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: All of the authors acknowledged Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: A.P. and T.A. conceived of the presented idea. A.P. developed the theory and performed the analysis. A.P. and A.Gh. verified the analytical methods. Z.H. and N.R. supervised the findings of this work. A.P. wrote the first draft of the paper. T.A. edited the manuscript. All authors discussed the results and contributed to the final manuscript.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The datasets generated and analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: This study complies with the Declaration of Helsinki and was performed according to ethics committee approval. The Ethics and Research Committee of the Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences approved the study (IR.HUMS.REC.1398.486). The records of all patients who provided informed consent for using their data for research purposes were analyzed. In cases of illiteracy, their legal guardians provided informed consent. Statistical analysis was performed with patient anonymity following ethics committee regulations.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
